title: Sentence Types — Declarative and Interrogative
description: Students learn to identify and write declarative sentences (statements) and interrogative sentences (questions). They examine punctuation differences and practice converting between the two types.
instructions:
1. Write a declarative sentence on the board: 'The Great Wall of China is very long.'
2. Ask what kind of sentence it is — it tells us something, it's a statement.
3. Write an interrogative sentence: 'How long is the Great Wall of China?'
4. Discuss: this one asks something. It's a question.
5. Point out the punctuation difference (period vs. question mark).
6. Practice: give students 5 declarative sentences to convert into questions, and 5 questions to convert into statements.
7. Students write 3 original declarative and 3 original interrogative sentences in their journals.

slides.setup_instructions: Have two example sentences pre-written on the board, covered until ready to reveal.

slides.text: Reveal the first sentence: 'The Great Wall of China is very long.' Ask: 'What does this sentence do? It tells us a fact. We call this a declarative sentence — it declares something. It ends with a period.'

Reveal the second sentence: 'How long is the Great Wall of China?' Ask: 'What does this one do? It asks a question! We call this an interrogative sentence. Interrogate means to ask questions. It ends with a question mark.'
Practice converting together: 'Pandas eat bamboo.' becomes 'Do pandas eat bamboo?' Show how the word order changes and the punctuation switches. Do three more together.

slides.prompt: Convert 5 declarative sentences into interrogative sentences and 5 interrogative sentences into declarative sentences. Then write 3 original sentences of each type in your journal.

slides.text: Review: A declarative sentence makes a statement and ends with a period. An interrogative sentence asks a question and ends with a question mark. Tomorrow we will learn two more sentence types!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify and write both declarative and interrogative sentences with correct punctuation?

parent_notes: This lesson introduces two of the four sentence types. In Montessori grammar, sentence analysis is a key part of understanding how language works. Encourage your child to find examples of each type in their reading throughout the week. Notice how news articles use mostly declarative sentences while interviews use interrogative ones.

title: Decimals — Introduction to Hundredths
description: Building on their understanding of tenths, students extend decimal place value to hundredths. They use the decimal board and hundred squares to visualize how one whole is divided into 100 equal parts.
instructions:
1. Review tenths: show the decimal board with 10 strips making one whole.
2. Take one tenth strip and divide it into 10 equal parts — each part is one hundredth.
3. Write 0.01 on the board. 'This is one hundredth. It takes 100 of these to make one whole.'
4. Show the hundred square grid: shade 1 square = 0.01, shade 10 squares = 0.10 = one tenth.
5. Practice reading decimals: 0.25 = 2 tenths and 5 hundredths = 25 hundredths.
6. Students shade hundred grids to represent various decimals: 0.15, 0.42, 0.73, 0.08, 0.90.
7. Write each decimal in expanded form (e.g., 0.42 = 4 tenths + 2 hundredths).
materials_needed: Hundred square grids (printed, at least 10 per student)
Place value chart extended to hundredths

slides.setup_instructions: Print multiple hundred square grids. Have the decimal board set up with the tenths strips from previous lessons.

slides.text: Review: 'Remember our tenths? One whole divided into 10 equal parts. Each part is one tenth, written 0.1.' Show on the decimal board. 'But what if we divide each tenth into 10 MORE parts?'

Hold up the hundred square grid. 'This whole square is ONE. It has 100 tiny squares inside. Each tiny square is one hundredth: 0.01.' Count out a row: 'Ten hundredths make one tenth: 0.10 equals 0.1.'
Write 0.25 on the board. Shade 25 squares on the grid. 'This is 2 tenths and 5 hundredths — or 25 hundredths. Both ways of reading it are correct.' Practice with 0.50, 0.73, and 0.08.

slides.prompt: Shade hundred grids to show each decimal: 0.15, 0.42, 0.73, 0.08, 0.90. Then write each in expanded form (tenths + hundredths). Challenge: what decimal does 100 shaded squares represent?

slides.text: One hundredth is written 0.01. The hundredths place is two places to the right of the decimal point. Ten hundredths equal one tenth, and one hundred hundredths equal one whole.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student read, write, and represent decimals to the hundredths place using hundred square grids?

parent_notes: Hundredths connect beautifully to money (pennies and dollars) and percentages. The hundred square grid is a powerful visual — 25 shaded squares clearly shows 0.25, which is also 25 cents or 25%. Let your child practice with real coins: 1 penny = $0.01 = one hundredth of a dollar.

title: Ancient China — The Great Wall
description: Students learn about the Great Wall of China — why it was built, how it was constructed over centuries by different dynasties, and what it reveals about ancient Chinese civilization. They locate it on the timeline and map.
instructions:
1. Place Ancient China on the timeline — it overlaps with Egypt and Mesopotamia.
2. Show China on the map. Point out its vast size and natural borders (Himalayas, Pacific Ocean).
3. Ask: 'What would you do if enemies kept attacking from the north?' Discuss defensive strategies.
4. Introduce the Great Wall: started by Qin Shi Huang around 221 BCE, but built over many dynasties.
5. Discuss construction: millions of workers, rammed earth and stone, watchtowers every few hundred meters.
6. Show images of the Wall winding across mountains.
7. Students draw a cross-section of the Wall showing its layers and a watchtower.
8. Add Ancient China to the class timeline.

slides.setup_instructions: Have the timeline visible with Egypt and Mesopotamia already marked. Print high-quality photos of the Great Wall from different angles.

slides.text: 'We have traveled through Mesopotamia, Egypt, and India. Today we journey east to CHINA!' Show China on the map. 'Look how enormous it is. Ancient Chinese civilization began along two great rivers — the Yellow River and the Yangtze River — around the same time as Egypt.'

'China had a big problem: nomadic warriors from the north kept raiding villages and stealing food. What would YOU do to protect your people?' Let the child brainstorm. 'Emperor Qin Shi Huang had a bold idea — build a wall across the ENTIRE northern border!'

'The Great Wall was not built all at once. Different dynasties added to it over about 2,000 years! Workers packed earth between wooden frames, then later used stone and brick. Watchtowers were built so guards could see enemies approaching and light signal fires to warn the next tower.'

slides.prompt: Draw a cross-section of the Great Wall showing: the stone/brick outer walls, the packed earth fill, a walkway on top wide enough for horses, and a watchtower. Label each part. On the back, write three facts you learned.

slides.text: The Great Wall stretches over 13,000 miles — longer than the distance from New York to Los Angeles and back! It took millions of workers and nearly 2,000 years. It is one of the greatest building achievements in human history.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student explain why the Great Wall was built, describe its basic construction, and locate China on a map?

parent_notes: Ancient China is a rich topic that will span several weeks. The Great Wall provides a dramatic entry point. If possible, watch a short documentary clip about the Wall. Discuss the human cost — many workers died during construction. This is an opportunity to talk about the ethics of massive building projects. Compare to the pyramids of Egypt.

title: China — Physical Features and Great Rivers
description: Students explore the physical geography of China: the Yellow River (Huang He), Yangtze River, Himalayan mountains, Gobi Desert, and eastern plains. They understand how geography shaped Chinese civilization.
instructions:
1. Show a physical map of China with elevation coloring.
2. Identify major features: Himalayas (south/southwest), Gobi Desert (north), Tibetan Plateau, eastern plains.
3. Trace the Yellow River (Huang He): 'Called the cradle of Chinese civilization.' Discuss the yellow silt.
4. Trace the Yangtze River: longest in Asia, flows through fertile farmland.
5. Discuss how geography isolated China: mountains, desert, and ocean on three sides.
6. Students create a labeled physical map of China showing: both rivers, Himalayas, Gobi Desert, Tibetan Plateau, Pacific Ocean, Great Wall location.
7. Color-code by elevation.
materials_needed: Colored pencils (blue, brown, green, yellow, tan)

slides.setup_instructions: Print a blank outline map of China. Have the physical elevation map displayed for reference.

slides.text: 'Let us look at China from above! See these colors on the map? Brown and white mean very high mountains. Green means low, flat plains. Yellow-tan means desert.' Point out the dramatic elevation changes from west to east.

'Here are the Himalayas — the tallest mountains on Earth — blocking the southwest. Here is the Gobi Desert in the north, one of the largest deserts in the world. And here is the Pacific Ocean to the east. China was naturally protected on almost every side!'

'Now the rivers: the Yellow River carries golden-yellow silt, which is why it is named Huang He — Yellow River. Farmers grew crops in this rich soil. The Yangtze is even longer — the third longest river in the world! It flows through the heart of China.'

slides.prompt: On your blank map of China, draw and label: the Yellow River (Huang He), the Yangtze River, the Himalayas, the Gobi Desert, the Tibetan Plateau, the Pacific Ocean, and where the Great Wall runs. Color-code by elevation: green for lowlands, brown for mountains, tan for desert, blue for water.

slides.text: China's geography made it like a natural fortress — protected by mountains, desert, and ocean. The two great rivers provided water and rich soil for farming. This is why Chinese civilization developed somewhat separately from the rest of the world.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify and locate the Yellow River, Yangtze River, Himalayas, Gobi Desert, and Pacific Ocean on a map of China?

parent_notes: China's geography is key to understanding its history. The natural barriers explain why the Great Wall was only needed along the northern border — the other sides were already protected. Compare China's rivers to the Nile, Tigris, and Euphrates. All ancient civilizations grew up along rivers. China has the largest population of any country (about 1.4 billion people), mostly concentrated in the eastern lowlands near the rivers.

title: Read Aloud — The Story of the Great Wall
description: A read-aloud session about the Great Wall of China, connecting to the history and geography lessons. Students listen, discuss, and respond to the text through conversation and illustration.
instructions:
1. Choose a read-aloud book about the Great Wall (suggestions: 'The Great Wall of China' by Leonard Everett Fisher, or a similar age-appropriate text).
2. Before reading: activate prior knowledge from today's lessons. 'What do we already know about the Great Wall?'
3. Read the text aloud, pausing for discussion at key points.
4. After reading: discuss new information learned. What surprised them?
5. Students write a short journal response: 'If I could walk along the Great Wall, I would see...'
6. Share responses aloud.
materials_needed: Book about the Great Wall of China

slides.setup_instructions: Select an age-appropriate book about the Great Wall. Preview it and mark good stopping points for discussion.

slides.text: Before reading: 'We learned about the Great Wall today in history and geography. What do you remember? Why was it built? How long is it?' Let the child share what they recall.

Read the book aloud with expression. Pause at key moments: 'Can you imagine carrying heavy stones up these steep mountains? What would that feel like?' Connect illustrations to what they learned earlier.
After reading: 'What new facts did you learn from this book that we did not cover in our lesson? What was the most surprising thing?' Discuss.

slides.prompt: In your reading journal, write a short paragraph beginning with: 'If I could walk along the Great Wall, I would see...' Include at least three details from today's lessons and the book. Add an illustration.

slides.text: Great writing! The Great Wall is a symbol of human determination and ingenuity. This week we will continue exploring Ancient China and discover even more amazing achievements.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student recall key facts from the read-aloud and connect them to prior learning about the Great Wall?

parent_notes: Read-alouds that connect to other subjects reinforce learning powerfully. If you cannot find a specific Great Wall book, search your library for any age-appropriate book about Ancient China. Online read-alouds on educational channels can also work. The journal writing connects literacy with history content.

title: Sentence Types — Imperative and Exclamatory
description: Students learn the remaining two sentence types: imperative (commands/requests) and exclamatory (strong feelings). They practice identifying all four types and using appropriate end punctuation.
instructions:
1. Review declarative and interrogative from yesterday.
2. Introduce imperative: 'Close the door.' 'Please pass the salt.' These are commands or requests.
3. Note: imperative sentences can end with a period or exclamation point depending on urgency.
4. Introduce exclamatory: 'What an amazing wall that is!' 'I can not believe how long it is!' These express strong emotion.
5. Always end with an exclamation point.
6. Practice: give 12 sentences for students to classify as declarative, interrogative, imperative, or exclamatory.
7. Students write 2 of each type, all related to Ancient China.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare 12 sentence cards (3 of each type). Make four labeled sorting areas on the table.

slides.text: Quick review: 'What are the two sentence types we learned yesterday?' Declarative = statement (period). Interrogative = question (question mark). 'Today we learn the last two!'

'Listen: Build the wall higher! Bring more stones! These sentences give commands — they tell someone to DO something. We call them imperative sentences. The subject (you) is usually hidden.' Write examples on the board.

'Now listen: The Great Wall is absolutely incredible! I cannot believe it is 13,000 miles long! These express STRONG feelings — excitement, surprise, amazement. We call them exclamatory sentences. They always end with an exclamation point!'

slides.prompt: Sort the 12 sentence cards into four categories: declarative, interrogative, imperative, and exclamatory. Then write 2 sentences of each type (8 total) about Ancient China in your journal. Use correct end punctuation!

slides.text: Now you know all four sentence types! Declarative tells (.), interrogative asks (?), imperative commands (. or !), and exclamatory shows strong feeling (!). Good writers use all four to make their writing interesting.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify and write all four sentence types with correct punctuation?

parent_notes: All four sentence types are now introduced. Over the coming days, encourage your child to identify sentence types in their reading. Play a game: read a passage and have them raise one finger for declarative, two for interrogative, three for imperative, and four for exclamatory. This builds automatic recognition.

title: Decimals — Comparing and Ordering Decimals
description: Students learn to compare decimals using place value understanding. They use hundred grids and number lines to visualize which decimal is greater and practice using the symbols <, >, and =.
instructions:
1. Review hundredths with the hundred grid.
2. Present two decimals: 0.3 and 0.25. Ask: 'Which is larger?'
3. Common mistake: students think 0.25 > 0.3 because 25 > 3. Show with grids: 0.3 = 30 hundredths, 0.25 = 25 hundredths.
4. Strategy: make both decimals have the same number of places (0.30 vs. 0.25).
5. Use a number line from 0 to 1 divided into hundredths to place decimals.
6. Practice: compare 10 pairs of decimals using <, >, =.
7. Order sets of 4-5 decimals from least to greatest.
materials_needed: Number line (0 to 1, marked in hundredths)

slides.setup_instructions: Draw a large number line from 0 to 1 on the board, marked at every tenth. Have hundred grids ready for visual comparison.

slides.text: 'Which is larger: 0.3 or 0.25? Think carefully before you answer.' Many children say 0.25 because 25 is bigger than 3. Shade both on hundred grids to see the truth: 0.3 = 30 squares, 0.25 = 25 squares. '0.3 is actually larger!'

'Here is a trick: make both numbers have the same number of decimal places. 0.3 becomes 0.30. Now compare 0.30 and 0.25. Since 30 hundredths > 25 hundredths, 0.30 > 0.25. Always compare place by place: tenths first, then hundredths.'
Place several decimals on the number line: 0.1, 0.45, 0.7, 0.05, 0.99. 'See how they spread out? Numbers further to the right are larger.' Practice comparing pairs using <, >, and = symbols.

slides.prompt: Compare 10 pairs of decimals using <, >, or =. Then order these sets from least to greatest: (a) 0.5, 0.05, 0.50, 0.55; (b) 0.8, 0.18, 0.81, 0.08; (c) 0.3, 0.33, 0.03, 0.30.

slides.text: When comparing decimals, always look at the tenths place first. If those are equal, look at the hundredths place. You can add a zero to make decimals the same length: 0.3 = 0.30. This does not change the value!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student correctly compare and order decimals to the hundredths place?

parent_notes: The key misconception to watch for is thinking that more digits after the decimal point means a larger number (e.g., thinking 0.25 > 0.3). The hundred grid is the best tool to combat this. Practice with money: 'Is $0.30 more than $0.25?' Children who understand money often grasp this more quickly.

title: Invertebrates — Introduction to Insects
description: Students begin studying invertebrates by exploring insects. They learn the three body parts (head, thorax, abdomen), six legs, and other defining characteristics that make an animal an insect.
instructions:
1. Review: 'We studied vertebrates — animals with backbones. Now we study INvertebrates — animals WITHOUT backbones. Most animals on Earth are invertebrates!'
2. Focus on insects: the largest group of invertebrates.
3. Show a diagram of an insect body: head (antennae, eyes, mouthparts), thorax (6 legs, wings), abdomen.
4. Key rule: if it has 3 body parts and 6 legs, it is an insect.
5. Sort pictures: is it an insect or not? (butterfly yes, spider no — 8 legs, worm no — no legs).
6. Students draw and label a detailed insect diagram.
7. Discuss: why are insects so successful? (small, reproduce quickly, can fly, diverse diets).
materials_needed: Pictures of various insects and non-insects for sorting

slides.setup_instructions: Print the insect anatomy diagram large enough to study. Prepare 15-20 pictures of animals to sort: 10 insects, 5-10 non-insects (spiders, centipedes, worms, crabs).

slides.text: 'We spent weeks studying vertebrates — fish, amphibians, reptiles, birds, and mammals. But did you know that 97% of all animal species are INvertebrates — animals WITHOUT a backbone? Today we start with the biggest group of all: INSECTS!'

Show the insect diagram. 'Every insect has THREE body sections: the HEAD (with eyes, antennae, and mouth), the THORAX (the middle section where the 6 legs and wings attach), and the ABDOMEN (the back section that holds the digestive and reproductive organs).'

'The golden rule: 3 body parts + 6 legs = insect. A spider has 8 legs — NOT an insect. A centipede has many legs — NOT an insect. A worm has no legs — NOT an insect.' Sort the pictures together, counting legs and body parts.

slides.prompt: Draw a large, detailed insect and label: head, thorax, abdomen, antennae, compound eyes, 6 legs (attached to thorax), wings. Then sort the remaining pictures into 'insect' and 'not an insect' piles, explaining your reasoning for each.

slides.text: Insects are the most successful animals on Earth — there are over one million known species! They live on every continent except Antarctica. Remember: 3 body parts, 6 legs, and usually wings. Next time, we will explore insect life cycles.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify the three body parts of an insect and distinguish insects from other arthropods?

parent_notes: Invertebrate study is a natural next step after vertebrates. Children are often fascinated by insects. Go on a bug hunt in your yard — use a magnifying glass to count legs and body sections on any insects you find. Remind your child that spiders are NOT insects (they are arachnids). This is a common misconception even among adults.

title: Chinese Art — Brush Painting (Ink Wash)
description: Students explore traditional Chinese brush painting (ink wash painting or sumi-e). They learn about the Four Treasures of the Study and practice basic brush strokes to create bamboo or orchid paintings.
instructions:
1. Introduce Chinese brush painting: one of the oldest art traditions, dating back thousands of years.
2. Explain the Four Treasures of the Study: brush, ink, paper, and inkstone.
3. Demonstrate how to hold the brush vertically (different from Western painting).
4. Show basic strokes: the dot, the horizontal stroke, the vertical stroke, the curve.
5. Practice strokes on scrap paper.
6. Guide students through painting bamboo: straight trunk strokes, angled branch strokes, leaf strokes.
7. Let students create their own bamboo painting on rice paper or watercolor paper.
8. Discuss how this connects to Ancient China.
materials_needed: Rice paper or white watercolor paper

slides.setup_instructions: Cover the workspace. Pre-mix ink to various dilutions (dark, medium, light) in separate containers. Have example paintings displayed.

slides.text: 'In Ancient China, painting was one of the most respected arts. Chinese artists used the Four Treasures of the Study: a brush, ink, paper, and an inkstone for grinding ink. Today we will paint in the Chinese style!'

'Chinese brushes are held straight up, not at an angle like Western pencils. This gives you more control.' Demonstrate: hold the brush vertically, use the whole arm to move. Show how pressing harder makes thick lines, and barely touching makes thin lines.

'We will paint bamboo — one of the most popular subjects in Chinese art. The straight trunk is just a series of segments.' Demonstrate: quick, confident strokes for the trunk. Thin branches at angles. Quick flicks for leaves. 'Speed and confidence are more important than perfection!'

slides.prompt: Practice the basic strokes on scrap paper first. Then create your own bamboo painting on good paper. Try varying your ink from dark to light by adding more water. Add a few leaves using quick, confident flicks of the brush.

slides.text: In Chinese culture, bamboo represents strength and flexibility — it bends in the wind but does not break. Chinese artists often paint bamboo to express these qualities. Your paintings capture the spirit of an art form that is over 2,000 years old!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student hold the brush vertically and create basic Chinese brush painting strokes to compose a simple bamboo painting?

parent_notes: Chinese brush painting is a wonderful complement to the Ancient China history lessons. The key technique is holding the brush vertically and using confident, quick strokes rather than careful, slow ones. If rice paper is unavailable, regular watercolor paper works. Emphasize that in Chinese art, empty space is just as important as the painted areas.

title: Tea Ceremony — Chinese Tea Preparation
description: Students learn about the Chinese tea ceremony and practice preparing and serving tea with grace and care. This connects to the Ancient China unit while developing practical life skills of pouring, serving, and hospitality.
instructions:
1. Discuss the history of tea: discovered in China around 2737 BCE according to legend.
2. Show the materials: teapot, cups, tea leaves (or herbal tea bags for children), hot water.
3. Demonstrate: warm the pot and cups with a little hot water first, add tea, pour water, wait.
4. Teach proper pouring: hold the pot lid with one finger, pour slowly and steadily.
5. Serving etiquette: offer to others before serving yourself, hold the cup with both hands.
6. Students prepare and serve tea, practicing careful pouring and polite manners.
7. Clean up: wash and dry all materials, put everything away.

slides.setup_instructions: Heat water ahead of time. Arrange all materials on a tray. Use herbal tea like chamomile or peppermint (no caffeine for children).

slides.text: 'Tea was discovered in Ancient China! Legend says Emperor Shen Nung was sitting under a tea tree when leaves blew into his hot water. He tasted it and loved it. Tea became one of China's greatest gifts to the world. Today we will prepare and serve tea the Chinese way.'

'First, we warm the pot and cups. Pour a little hot water in, swirl it around, and pour it out. This prepares the vessels and keeps the tea warm longer.' Demonstrate slowly and carefully. 'Now add the tea leaves (or bag) and pour in the hot water. We wait patiently for it to steep.'

'When pouring, hold the lid with one finger and pour slowly and steadily. Fill each cup only about three-quarters full. In Chinese tradition, you always serve others before yourself. Hold your cup with both hands to show respect and appreciation.'

slides.prompt: Prepare tea following the steps demonstrated. Pour carefully for each person, serving others first. Sit quietly and enjoy your tea, practicing holding the cup with both hands. When finished, wash and dry all the tea materials and put them away.

slides.text: Tea preparation teaches us patience, care, and hospitality. In China, serving tea is a way of showing respect and building friendships. You practiced pouring carefully, serving others first, and cleaning up — all important life skills!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student safely prepare and pour tea, demonstrate serving etiquette, and clean up all materials?

parent_notes: This practical life activity beautifully integrates with the Ancient China unit. Always supervise hot water handling. Use caffeine-free herbal tea. The emphasis on serving others first and holding cups with both hands teaches grace and courtesy — core Montessori values. If you have any Chinese tea accessories (gaiwan, small cups), use them for authenticity.

title: Creative Writing — Planning a Short Story
description: Students learn the elements of a short story (character, setting, problem, solution) and plan their own original short story using a story map graphic organizer. The story will be written over several sessions.
instructions:
1. Discuss: 'What makes a story a story?' It needs characters, a setting, a problem, and a solution.
2. Use a familiar story as an example — break it into these four elements.
3. Introduce the story map: a graphic organizer with boxes for Character, Setting, Problem, Events (beginning, middle, end), and Solution.
4. Brainstorm story ideas together — encourage China-inspired themes but allow any topic.
5. Students complete their story map, planning each element.
6. Share story plans with a partner or parent.
7. Explain: tomorrow they will begin writing the actual story.

slides.setup_instructions: Print story map templates. Have a completed example story map to show as a model.

slides.text: 'Every great story has four key ingredients: CHARACTERS (who is it about?), SETTING (where and when does it happen?), PROBLEM (what goes wrong or what challenge do they face?), and SOLUTION (how is the problem solved?). Let us look at a story we know and find these ingredients.'

Use a familiar story (fairy tale or recently-read book) and identify each element together. Write them on the board. 'See? Every story follows this pattern. Even movies and TV shows have these same ingredients!'

'Now it is YOUR turn to plan an original story! Use this story map to organize your ideas. You might write about an adventure on the Great Wall, or a journey along the Silk Road, or anything you wish! First, decide on your character and setting, then think of an interesting problem.'

slides.prompt: Complete your story map: describe your main character (name, age, personality), your setting (where and when), the problem they face, 3 main events (beginning, middle, end), and how the problem is solved. Be as detailed as you can — this is your blueprint!

slides.text: Share your story plan! Great writers always plan before they write. Your story map is like an architect's blueprint — it shows you what to build. Tomorrow we will start writing the actual story using this plan as our guide.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student plan a short story with identifiable characters, setting, problem, and solution using a graphic organizer?

parent_notes: Story planning is a crucial writing skill. Many children want to jump straight into writing, but planning produces much better stories. The story map acts as a scaffold. Do not worry about perfection at this stage — the goal is to generate ideas and organize them. The actual writing will happen in upcoming sessions. Encourage creative and original ideas rather than retelling known stories.

title: Decimals — Addition of Decimals
description: Students learn to add decimals by lining up the decimal points. They use hundred grids for visual support and practice adding tenths and hundredths with and without regrouping.
instructions:
1. Review: adding whole numbers — we line up the ones, tens, hundreds. With decimals, we line up the DECIMAL POINTS.
2. Demonstrate: 0.3 + 0.4. Shade 30 squares, then shade 40 more squares on the same grid = 70 squares = 0.7.
3. Demonstrate with column addition: write vertically, line up decimal points, add column by column.
4. Practice: 0.25 + 0.13 = ? Shade and add. Line up and add. Both methods give 0.38.
5. With regrouping: 0.47 + 0.35 = ? 7 hundredths + 5 hundredths = 12 hundredths = 1 tenth and 2 hundredths.
6. Practice set of 8 problems, increasing difficulty.
7. Word problems involving money as decimals.

slides.setup_instructions: Print plenty of hundred grids. Have two different colored pencils ready for shading the two addends in different colors.

slides.text: 'When we add whole numbers, we line up the ones place. When we add decimals, we line up the DECIMAL POINTS.' Write 0.3 + 0.4 vertically on the board with decimal points aligned. 'Then we add each column just like we always do.'

Show on the hundred grid: shade 30 squares in blue (0.3), then shade 40 more in red (0.4). Count total: 70 squares = 0.7. 'See how the grid matches our column addition? Both give us 0.7!' Now try 0.25 + 0.13 with both methods.

'What about 0.47 + 0.35? In the hundredths column: 7 + 5 = 12. That is more than 9, so we regroup! 12 hundredths = 1 tenth and 2 hundredths. Carry the 1 to the tenths column: 4 + 3 + 1 = 8 tenths. Answer: 0.82.' Verify with the grid.

slides.prompt: Solve these decimal addition problems, lining up the decimal points: (1) 0.6 + 0.3, (2) 0.14 + 0.25, (3) 0.38 + 0.41, (4) 0.56 + 0.27, (5) 0.75 + 0.18, (6) 0.9 + 0.45. Use hundred grids to check at least 3 of your answers.

slides.text: The key to adding decimals: line up the decimal points, then add just like whole numbers. If you have different numbers of decimal places, add a zero to make them match (0.9 = 0.90). Regrouping works the same way as with whole numbers.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student add decimals to the hundredths place, including problems that require regrouping?

parent_notes: Decimal addition follows the same rules as whole number addition — the only new concept is lining up the decimal points. Money is a perfect real-world connection: $0.75 + $0.18 = $0.93. Practice with coins and prices during shopping trips. The hundred grid provides a visual check: shade one addend, shade the other, count the total.

title: Ancient China — The Silk Road
description: Students learn about the Silk Road trade network that connected China to the Mediterranean world. They explore what was traded, how goods traveled, and how ideas and cultures spread along the route.
instructions:
1. Review: 'China had the Great Wall to protect its borders. But China also traded with the outside world. How?'
2. Introduce the Silk Road: not one road but a network of routes stretching 4,000 miles.
3. Show the route on a map: from Chang'an (Xi'an) in China across Central Asia to Rome.
4. What was traded: silk, spices, tea, porcelain FROM China; gold, glass, horses, wool TO China.
5. Discuss: traders did not usually travel the whole route. Goods passed through many hands.
6. Cultural exchange: religions (Buddhism), inventions, foods, and languages spread along the road.
7. Students trace the Silk Road on a map and draw pictures of traded goods at each end.
materials_needed: Sample materials if available (silk fabric, spices)
Yarn or string to trace the route on a wall map

items: Sample silk fabric and spices (if available)
slides.setup_instructions: Display a large map of Eurasia. Have yarn ready to trace the Silk Road route. If possible, bring silk fabric and spices for children to touch and smell.

slides.text: 'China had something the rest of the world wanted desperately: SILK. This beautiful, shiny fabric came from silkworms, and only the Chinese knew how to make it. People in Rome, Persia, and India would pay a fortune for silk. But how did it get there?'

'The Silk Road! It was not one road but a whole network of paths stretching over 4,000 miles — from China all the way to Rome.' Trace the route on the map with yarn. 'It crossed deserts, mountain passes, and grasslands. The journey could take over a year!'

'Traders did not just carry silk. From China: silk, tea, spices, porcelain, paper, and gunpowder. From the West: gold, silver, glass, horses, and wool. Along with goods, IDEAS traveled too — religions like Buddhism, new inventions, and different foods spread along the Silk Road.'

slides.prompt: On your map, trace the Silk Road route from Chang'an to Rome. At the China end, draw and label 5 goods that traveled westward. At the Rome end, draw and label 5 goods that traveled eastward. In the middle, write 'IDEAS' and list 3 things that spread along the road.

slides.text: The Silk Road was one of history's most important trade routes. It connected East and West, allowing not just goods but ideas, religions, and inventions to spread across continents. Even today, we benefit from the cultural exchange that happened along the Silk Road.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student describe the Silk Road, identify goods traded in both directions, and trace the general route on a map?

parent_notes: The Silk Road is a fascinating topic because it shows how interconnected the ancient world really was. If possible, let your child feel real silk and smell spices like cinnamon and pepper — these were among the most valuable trade goods. The concept of cultural exchange (ideas traveling along with goods) is an important one for children to understand.

title: Chinese Inventions — Paper and Printing
description: Students learn about two of China's Four Great Inventions: papermaking and printing. They explore how these inventions changed the world and try making simple paper or printing with carved stamps.
instructions:
1. Ask: 'What do you write on? Where does paper come from?'
2. Before paper: people wrote on bamboo strips, silk, clay tablets, papyrus. All had drawbacks.
3. Cai Lun (105 CE) invented paper from bark, rags, and plant fibers. Revolutionary!
4. Later, the Chinese invented woodblock printing: carve text backwards into a block, ink it, press onto paper.
5. Even later: movable type — individual character stamps that could be rearranged.
6. Discuss impact: books could be made faster and cheaper. Knowledge spread!
7. Activity: students make simple prints using carved potatoes or foam stamps.
materials_needed: Potatoes (halved) or foam blocks for carving stamps
Examples of different writing surfaces (if available)

slides.setup_instructions: Pre-cut potatoes in half. Have ink pads and paper ready. Display images of ancient Chinese woodblock printing.

slides.text: 'Before paper was invented, people had to write on bamboo strips, animal skins, silk, or clay tablets. Imagine carrying a book made of bamboo — it could weigh 50 pounds! Then around 105 CE, a Chinese official named Cai Lun found a way to make thin, light sheets from tree bark and old rags. PAPER!'

'Paper was amazing, but copying a book still meant writing every word by hand. Then Chinese inventors created woodblock printing — they carved an entire page of text into a wooden block, inked it, and pressed it onto paper. One block could make thousands of copies!'

'Later came movable type: individual stamps for each character that could be rearranged to print any page. These inventions changed the world — suddenly books became affordable and knowledge spread to millions of people. We will try printing ourselves!'

slides.prompt: Carve a simple design or letter (backwards!) into your potato or foam block. Ink it and press it onto paper. Make multiple copies — just like the ancient Chinese printers did! Try creating a repeating pattern or a simple message.

slides.text: Paper and printing are two of China's Four Great Inventions. Without them, books, newspapers, and the spread of knowledge as we know it would not exist. Next time you write on paper or read a printed page, remember — that technology came from Ancient China!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student explain how papermaking and printing were invented in China and why these inventions were important?

parent_notes: Paper and printing are arguably China's most impactful inventions. You can extend this lesson by trying actual papermaking — there are many simple tutorials online using a blender, screen, and recycled paper. The potato/foam printing activity gives children a hands-on feel for how woodblock printing works. Remind them that the image must be carved in REVERSE to print correctly — this is a great problem-solving challenge.

title: Read Aloud — The Silk Road Journey
description: A read-aloud session featuring a story or informational text about traveling the Silk Road. Students listen, visualize the journey, and connect to their history lesson.
instructions:
1. Choose a book about the Silk Road (suggestions: 'Traveling the Silk Road' or a similar children's text; or read a chapter from an encyclopedia/history book about the Silk Road).
2. Before reading: review the Silk Road map from today's history lesson.
3. As you read, pause to locate places mentioned on the map.
4. After reading: discuss the hardships of traveling the Silk Road (desert heat, mountain cold, bandits, sandstorms).
5. Students write a diary entry from the perspective of a Silk Road trader.
6. Share diary entries.
materials_needed: Book or text about the Silk Road

slides.setup_instructions: Select an age-appropriate text about the Silk Road. Have the map from history class visible for reference.

slides.text: 'Today we are going to imagine ourselves as traders on the Silk Road. Before we read, look at our map. The journey from China to Rome was over 4,000 miles. What do you think that journey was like?'

Read the text aloud. Pause at key points: 'The traders entered the Taklamakan Desert — its name means Go in and you will not come out. Imagine the heat, the sand in your eyes, the thirst.' Point to locations on the map as they appear in the text.
After reading, discuss: 'What were the biggest dangers? Why did people risk this journey? What would you have traded?' Connect to the goods discussed in history: silk, spices, gold, glass.

slides.prompt: Write a diary entry as a Silk Road trader. Begin: 'Day 47 on the Silk Road...' Describe where you are, what you are carrying, what you have seen, and one challenge you faced today. Use details from the book and our lessons.

slides.text: Your diary entries brought the Silk Road to life! Writing from a character's perspective helps us understand what life was really like in the past. The Silk Road traders were brave and adventurous people.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student describe details of Silk Road travel and write a creative journal entry from a trader's perspective?

parent_notes: Perspective writing (writing as a character from history) is a powerful tool for developing empathy and deep understanding. If you cannot find a specific Silk Road book, use encyclopedia entries or online articles read aloud. The diary entry exercise combines creative writing with historical knowledge — a hallmark of Montessori cross-curricular learning.

title: Creative Writing — Drafting a Short Story (Part 1)
description: Using their story maps from Day 3, students begin drafting their short stories. They focus on writing a strong beginning that introduces the character, setting, and hints at the problem.
instructions:
1. Review the student's story map from Day 3.
2. Discuss strong story openings: action, dialogue, or a vivid description of the setting.
3. Read examples of good opening paragraphs from published stories.
4. Model: write the opening paragraph of a sample story on the board.
5. Students draft their own opening paragraph (the beginning section of their story map).
6. Continue into the middle events if time allows.
7. Peer or parent review of the opening: Is the character introduced? Is the setting clear? Do we know there will be a problem?
materials_needed: Student's completed story map from Day 3

slides.setup_instructions: Have the student's story map visible for reference. Mark several strong opening paragraphs in published books.

slides.text: 'Today we begin writing! A great story needs a great beginning. Here are three ways to start: with ACTION (Something exciting happening), with DIALOGUE (A character speaking), or with DESCRIPTION (Painting a picture of the setting with words).' Read an example of each.

Model by writing an opening paragraph on the board: 'The wind howled across the Great Wall as Li Wei pressed herself against the cold stone. She was supposed to be home by sunset, but the discovery she had made in the watchtower changed everything.' Discuss: what do we learn? (character, setting, hint of problem)

'Now look at YOUR story map. Who is your character? Where are they? What hint can you give about the problem? Write your opening paragraph — at least 4-5 sentences. Then continue with the events of your story.'

slides.prompt: Using your story map as a guide, write the beginning of your short story. Include: introduce your main character, describe the setting, and hint at the problem. Then continue writing into the middle events. Aim for at least one full page.

slides.text: Read your opening paragraph aloud. Does it hook the reader? Does it introduce the character and setting? Great work! We will continue writing tomorrow, working on the middle and end of the story.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student write a story opening that introduces character, setting, and hints at the problem?

parent_notes: The drafting stage is where the story map pays off. Encourage your child to follow their plan but also be open to new ideas that emerge during writing. Do not focus on spelling and grammar during drafting — the goal is to get ideas on paper. There will be time for editing later. If your child gets stuck, refer back to the story map for direction.

title: Decimals — Subtraction of Decimals
description: Students learn to subtract decimals by lining up the decimal points, following the same procedure as addition. They practice with and without regrouping (borrowing) and use hundred grids for verification.
instructions:
1. Review decimal addition from yesterday — same rules apply to subtraction.
2. Demonstrate: 0.8 - 0.3. Show on hundred grid: shade 80 squares, cross out 30. Remaining: 50 = 0.5.
3. Column subtraction: line up decimal points, subtract column by column.
4. With regrouping: 0.72 - 0.45. In hundredths: 2 - 5, need to borrow. 12 - 5 = 7 hundredths. 6 - 4 = 2 tenths. Answer: 0.27.
5. Tricky case: 0.5 - 0.23. Write 0.5 as 0.50 first, then subtract.
6. Practice set of 8 problems.
7. Word problems: 'You have $0.75 and spend $0.48. How much is left?'

slides.setup_instructions: Print hundred grids. Have the place value chart visible. Prepare practice problems of increasing difficulty.

slides.text: 'Subtracting decimals works just like adding them — line up the decimal points and subtract column by column.' Show 0.8 - 0.3 on a hundred grid: shade 80 squares, cross out 30. Count remaining: 50 = 0.5. Show the same problem in column form.

'What about 0.72 - 0.45? Look at the hundredths: 2 - 5. We cannot do that! So we borrow from the tenths, just like with whole numbers. Now it is 12 - 5 = 7 hundredths, and 6 - 4 = 2 tenths. Answer: 0.27.' Verify on the hundred grid.

'Here is a tricky one: 0.5 - 0.23. The numbers have different lengths! The trick: rewrite 0.5 as 0.50. Now we can subtract: 0.50 - 0.23 = 0.27.' Adding a zero after the last decimal digit does not change the value. Practice: 0.6 - 0.14, 0.9 - 0.37.

slides.prompt: Solve: (1) 0.9 - 0.4, (2) 0.67 - 0.31, (3) 0.83 - 0.56, (4) 0.70 - 0.25, (5) 0.5 - 0.18, (6) 1.0 - 0.64. Word problem: You have $0.75 and buy a sticker for $0.48. How much change do you receive?

slides.text: Subtracting decimals uses the same rules as adding them: line up the decimal points, add zeros if needed to make the numbers the same length, then subtract column by column with regrouping when necessary. You now know how to add AND subtract decimals!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student subtract decimals to the hundredths place, including problems requiring regrouping and filling in trailing zeros?

parent_notes: The biggest challenges with decimal subtraction are: (1) remembering to line up the decimal point, (2) handling numbers with different numbers of decimal places, and (3) regrouping across the decimal point. Money problems are excellent practice since children are motivated to figure out how much change they get. Practice with real coins at the store.

title: Insect Life Cycles — Complete Metamorphosis
description: Students learn about complete metamorphosis: the four-stage life cycle of insects like butterflies, beetles, and flies (egg, larva, pupa, adult). They compare this to incomplete metamorphosis.
instructions:
1. Review insect body parts from Day 2.
2. Ask: 'Does a caterpillar look like a butterfly? They are the same animal! How is that possible?'
3. Introduce metamorphosis: a dramatic change in form during an insect's life.
4. Complete metamorphosis has 4 stages: egg, larva (caterpillar), pupa (chrysalis/cocoon), adult.
5. Show images of each stage for a butterfly and a beetle.
6. Briefly mention incomplete metamorphosis: egg, nymph, adult (grasshopper). Only 3 stages.
7. Students create a circular life cycle diagram for a butterfly showing all 4 stages with illustrations.
8. Compare: butterfly vs. grasshopper life cycles.
materials_needed: Drawing paper (circular format or paper plates)
Optional: live caterpillars or butterfly kit

slides.setup_instructions: Print clear images of butterfly and beetle life cycle stages. Prepare paper plates divided into 4 sections for the life cycle diagram.

slides.text: 'Look at this caterpillar. Now look at this butterfly. Would you believe they are the SAME animal? This amazing transformation is called METAMORPHOSIS — it comes from Greek words meaning change of form.'

'Complete metamorphosis has FOUR stages: (1) EGG — the mother lays tiny eggs on a plant. (2) LARVA — a caterpillar hatches and eats constantly, growing bigger and bigger. (3) PUPA — the caterpillar forms a chrysalis and its body completely transforms inside. (4) ADULT — a butterfly emerges with wings!'

'Not all insects go through 4 stages. Some, like grasshoppers, have INCOMPLETE metamorphosis — only 3 stages: egg, nymph (a small version of the adult), and adult. The nymph looks like a tiny adult and just grows bigger, shedding its skin as it grows. No pupa stage!'

slides.prompt: Create a circular life cycle diagram on a paper plate. Divide it into 4 sections and illustrate: egg, larva (caterpillar), pupa (chrysalis), and adult (butterfly). Label each stage and draw arrows showing the direction. On the back, write 2-3 sentences about each stage.

slides.text: Complete metamorphosis is one of nature's most amazing processes. The caterpillar literally dissolves inside the chrysalis and rebuilds itself as a butterfly! Butterflies, beetles, flies, and ants all go through complete metamorphosis. Grasshoppers and dragonflies use incomplete metamorphosis.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student describe the four stages of complete metamorphosis and explain the difference from incomplete metamorphosis?

parent_notes: Metamorphosis is one of the most captivating science topics for children. Consider ordering a butterfly kit to observe the process in real time — watching a caterpillar form a chrysalis and emerge as a butterfly is unforgettable. Many educational supply companies sell them. The process takes about 3 weeks. If that is not possible, excellent time-lapse videos are available online.

title: Geometry — Exploring Symmetry
description: Students explore line symmetry through hands-on activities. They identify lines of symmetry in shapes, letters, and real objects, and create symmetrical designs using folding and painting techniques.
instructions:
1. Fold a piece of paper in half and cut out a shape. Unfold: both sides match! This is symmetry.
2. Define line of symmetry: a line that divides a shape into two mirror-image halves.
3. Test shapes: does a square have a line of symmetry? (Yes — 4!) Rectangle? (Yes — 2.) Triangle? (Depends on the type.)
4. Test letters: A, B, C, D... which have vertical symmetry? Horizontal? Both?
5. Look for symmetry in nature: butterflies, leaves, faces, flowers.
6. Activity: fold paper, drop paint on one side, fold and press — open to reveal a symmetrical design.
7. Draw 5 shapes and mark all lines of symmetry.

slides.setup_instructions: Pre-cut some geometric shapes from paper. Have mirrors and paint ready. Cover the workspace for the paint activity.

slides.text: 'Watch this: I fold this paper in half and cut a shape along the fold. When I open it... both sides are exactly the same! This is called SYMMETRY. The fold line is called the LINE OF SYMMETRY — it divides the shape into two matching halves.'

'How can we test for symmetry? Place a mirror along a line. If the reflection and the real shape together look like the original shape, that is a line of symmetry!' Test a square: 'It has FOUR lines of symmetry — horizontal, vertical, and two diagonal.' Test a rectangle: 'Only TWO — horizontal and vertical. The diagonals do not work!'

'Symmetry is everywhere in nature! Butterflies have perfect symmetry. Your face is almost symmetrical. Flowers often have multiple lines of symmetry. Even Chinese art uses symmetry in its designs.' Show examples.

slides.prompt: Part 1: Fold paper in half, drip paint on one side, fold and press, then open to see your symmetrical design. Part 2: Draw these shapes and mark ALL lines of symmetry: square, rectangle, equilateral triangle, circle, regular hexagon. How many does each have?

slides.text: A line of symmetry divides a shape into two mirror-image halves. Some shapes have many lines of symmetry (a circle has infinite!), while some shapes have none. Look for symmetry in nature, art, and architecture this week!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify and draw lines of symmetry for basic geometric shapes?

parent_notes: Symmetry is a geometry concept that connects beautifully to art and nature. The paint-fold activity produces stunning results and is very memorable. After this lesson, go on a symmetry hunt around your home and neighborhood — architecture, nature, and design all use symmetry. The mirror test is an excellent hands-on way to verify lines of symmetry.

title: Chinese Music — Pentatonic Scale and Instruments
description: Students learn about traditional Chinese music, the pentatonic scale, and Chinese instruments. They listen to examples and experiment with creating pentatonic melodies.
instructions:
1. Introduce Chinese music: one of the oldest musical traditions in the world.
2. The pentatonic scale uses 5 notes (penta = five). On a piano: C, D, E, G, A (no F or B).
3. Play or listen to a pentatonic melody — it sounds distinctly Asian/Chinese.
4. Introduce instruments: erhu (2-string fiddle), pipa (lute), guzheng (zither), dizi (bamboo flute).
5. Listen to recordings of each instrument.
6. Students experiment with pentatonic melodies on available instruments (xylophone, piano, or tone bars — remove F and B bars).
7. Create a simple composition using only pentatonic notes.
materials_needed: Images of Chinese instruments (erhu, pipa, guzheng, dizi)
Optional: remove F and B bars from xylophone

slides.setup_instructions: Queue up audio/video recordings of erhu, pipa, guzheng, and dizi performances. If using a xylophone, remove the F and B bars to create a pentatonic instrument.

slides.text: 'Chinese music is one of the oldest in the world — over 3,000 years old! It sounds different from Western music because it uses a special scale with only FIVE notes instead of seven. This is called the PENTATONIC scale. Penta means five, like pentagon.'

'Let us hear some traditional Chinese instruments.' Play recordings: 'The ERHU is like a violin with only two strings — listen to its singing, emotional sound. The PIPA is like a guitar played upright. The GUZHENG has 21 strings stretched across a long board. The DIZI is a bamboo flute.' Show images of each.

'Now let us make our own pentatonic music! On the xylophone, we only use these notes: C, D, E, G, A. Play any combination of these notes and it will sound beautiful — you almost cannot make a mistake with the pentatonic scale!' Demonstrate a simple melody.

slides.prompt: Experiment with the pentatonic scale (C, D, E, G, A) on the xylophone or keyboard. Create a short melody — at least 8 notes long. Practice it until you can play it smoothly. Write down your melody using letter names so you can remember it.

slides.text: The pentatonic scale is the foundation of Chinese music, but it is also found in music from Japan, Africa, Scotland, and even American blues! When you hear music that sounds Asian, it is often because it uses these same five notes.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify the pentatonic scale and create a simple melody using only pentatonic notes?

parent_notes: The pentatonic scale is magical because almost any combination of its five notes sounds pleasing. This makes it perfect for children's first composition experience. YouTube has excellent performances of all four instruments mentioned. The connection between Chinese music and the pentatonic scale is a great example of how culture influences art. Even many Western songs use the pentatonic scale (Amazing Grace, for example).

title: Creative Writing — Completing and Revising the Short Story
description: Students finish drafting their short stories, then learn basic revision strategies: adding detail, checking sentence variety, and reading aloud to catch errors.
instructions:
1. Students continue writing from where they left off on Day 4.
2. Focus on the ending: the problem must be solved, the character must have changed or learned something.
3. Once the draft is complete, introduce revision:
   - Read aloud: does it sound natural? Are there awkward sentences?
   - Check for sentence variety: do all sentences start the same way? Mix short and long sentences.
   - Add detail: find two places to add descriptive words or dialogue.
4. Students revise their stories based on these three checks.
5. Write a final copy or prepare to share.
6. Author's chair: students read their stories aloud to the class/family.

slides.setup_instructions: Have the student's draft ready. Prepare a simple revision checklist: (1) Read aloud, (2) Sentence variety, (3) Add details.

slides.text: 'Today we finish our stories and make them even better! First, complete your story. Remember: the ending must solve the problem. Your character should have changed or learned something. A good ending leaves the reader satisfied.'

'Now let us revise. First: READ ALOUD. When you hear your story out loud, you catch things your eyes miss. Second: CHECK SENTENCE VARIETY — not every sentence should start with The or I. Mix it up! Third: ADD DETAIL — find two places where you can add a descriptive word or a line of dialogue.'

'Use a colored pencil to make revision marks on your draft. Add a caret (^) where you want to insert words. Cross out words you want to remove. Draw an arrow if you want to move a sentence. Revision is what turns good writing into GREAT writing!'

slides.prompt: Complete your story draft if not yet finished. Then revise using the three-step checklist: (1) read aloud and fix awkward parts, (2) vary your sentence beginnings, (3) add descriptive details in at least two places. When ready, write your final copy neatly or prepare to read aloud.

slides.text: Author's chair! Read your story aloud to your audience. You planned, drafted, and revised an original short story this week. That is what real authors do! Your story has characters, a setting, a problem, and a solution — all the ingredients of great fiction.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student complete a short story with a clear beginning, middle, and end, and demonstrate basic revision skills?

parent_notes: Completing a full short story — from planning to drafting to revision — is a major accomplishment. Celebrate your child's work! The revision process is particularly important: professional writers revise many times. Help your child see that revision is not about fixing mistakes but about making good writing even better. Save these stories in a writing portfolio.

title: Decimals — Word Problems and Review
description: Students apply their decimal skills to real-world word problems involving money, measurement, and everyday situations. This lesson reviews all decimal concepts from the week: hundredths, comparing, adding, and subtracting.
instructions:
1. Quick review: reading decimals, comparing, adding, subtracting.
2. Present word problems involving money:
   - 'A book costs $4.75 and a bookmark costs $1.25. What is the total?'
   - 'You have $5.00 and buy a snack for $2.38. How much change?'
3. Present measurement problems:
   - 'A caterpillar is 3.5 cm long. It grows 1.8 cm. How long is it now?'
4. Students solve a set of 8-10 word problems independently.
5. Challenge: multi-step problems combining addition and subtraction.
6. Students create their own word problem for a partner to solve.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare 8-10 word problems of increasing difficulty. Have play money available for students who need a concrete model.

slides.text: Quick review: 'This week we learned about hundredths, comparing decimals, adding decimals, and subtracting decimals. Today we use ALL of those skills to solve real-world problems. The key to word problems: read carefully, decide the operation, line up the decimal points, and solve.'

Model a problem: 'A book costs $4.75 and a bookmark costs $1.25. What is the total?' Identify: we need to ADD. Set up: 4.75 + 1.25. Line up decimal points. Solve: $6.00. Check: does this make sense? Yes, about $5 + $1 = $6.

Model a subtraction problem: 'You have $5.00 and buy a snack for $2.38. How much change?' Set up: 5.00 - 2.38. Solve: $2.62. Estimation check: $5 - $2 = about $3. Our answer $2.62 is close, so it makes sense.

slides.prompt: Solve 8 word problems involving decimals (money and measurement). Show your work and check each answer with estimation. Then create your own decimal word problem and write it on a separate paper — include the answer key on the back!

slides.text: You have mastered decimals to the hundredths place this week! You can read them, compare them, add them, and subtract them. Decimals are everywhere: money, measurements, sports scores, and science. Keep practicing with real-life situations!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student solve multi-step word problems involving decimal addition and subtraction in real-world contexts?

parent_notes: Word problems are the ultimate test of mathematical understanding because they require students to choose the correct operation, not just compute. Practice at home: have your child calculate the total at the grocery store, figure out change, or measure objects and add/subtract the measurements. Creating their own word problems is an especially powerful learning activity.

title: China — Population, Cities, and Modern Life
description: Students explore modern China: its enormous population, major cities (Beijing, Shanghai, Hong Kong), and how ancient traditions blend with modern life. They compare population density to other countries.
instructions:
1. China's population: about 1.4 billion people — the most of any country until recently passed by India.
2. Compare: 'If our class had 100 students, 18 of them would be Chinese.' Use proportional representation.
3. Show major cities on the map: Beijing (capital, Forbidden City), Shanghai (largest, modern skyline), Hong Kong (harbor city).
4. Discuss: most people live in the eastern part of China near rivers. Western China is mostly empty (mountains, desert).
5. Modern vs. ancient: high-speed trains alongside ancient temples, smartphones alongside calligraphy.
6. Students create an infographic about China: population, area, capital, major cities, fun facts.
7. Compare China's population to their own country.
materials_needed: Photos of modern and ancient China

items: Photos of modern and ancient China
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare population comparison data. Print photos showing the contrast of ancient and modern China side by side.

slides.text: 'China has about 1.4 BILLION people. That is 1,400,000,000! If you counted one person per second, it would take you about 44 YEARS to count everyone in China. About 1 out of every 6 people on Earth lives in China!'

'Where do all these people live? Look at the map — almost everyone lives in the EASTERN half, near the rivers and coast. The west has the Himalayas, the Tibetan Plateau, and the Gobi Desert — very hard to live in! The biggest cities are Beijing (the capital), Shanghai (the largest), and Hong Kong.'

Show contrasting photos: 'Modern China has the fastest trains in the world, incredible skyscrapers, and cutting-edge technology. But it also preserves ancient traditions: calligraphy, tea ceremonies, martial arts, and festivals like Chinese New Year. Ancient and modern exist side by side.'

slides.prompt: Create a China infographic on a large sheet of paper. Include: the country name in both English and Chinese characters, population, area, capital city, 3 major cities, 2 rivers, and 5 fun facts from this week's lessons. Add illustrations and make it colorful!

slides.text: This week we explored Ancient China and modern China. We learned about the Great Wall, the Silk Road, Chinese inventions, rivers and mountains, and the enormous population. China's civilization is over 4,000 years old and still thriving today!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student describe China's population distribution, locate major cities, and explain how ancient traditions coexist with modern life?

parent_notes: This lesson brings the Ancient China unit into the present day. Children are often amazed by the scale of China's population. The infographic activity synthesizes the entire week's learning. If possible, visit a Chinese restaurant this week and talk about how Chinese food in America differs from traditional Chinese cuisine. You might also explore Chinese New Year traditions if the timing is right.

title: Chinese Inventions — Compass and Gunpowder
description: Students learn about the remaining two of China's Four Great Inventions: the magnetic compass and gunpowder. They explore how these inventions spread along the Silk Road and changed the world.
instructions:
1. Review: 'We learned about paper and printing. Today: two more inventions that changed everything.'
2. The compass: Chinese discovered that a lodestone points north. Used for navigation.
3. Demonstrate with a simple compass: how it always points north. Discuss why this matters for travelers.
4. Gunpowder: originally created by Chinese alchemists looking for an elixir of life! First used for fireworks.
5. Later used for weapons, which changed warfare forever.
6. Both inventions traveled along the Silk Road to the rest of the world.
7. Students create a 'Four Great Inventions' poster showing all four inventions with dates and descriptions.
materials_needed: Magnet and needle (for DIY compass demonstration)
Images of all Four Great Inventions
Bowl of water and cork (for floating needle compass)

slides.setup_instructions: Have a real compass ready to demonstrate. Prepare materials for a simple DIY compass: magnetize a needle by stroking it with a magnet, place on a cork floating in water.

slides.text: 'The Chinese discovered something amazing about a special rock called LODESTONE — it always points the same direction! They realized it points NORTH. Imagine how useful that is: even in fog, in the dark, or on the open ocean, you always know which way is north. They invented the COMPASS!'

Demonstrate with a real compass and a DIY floating needle compass. 'See? No matter which way we turn it, the needle swings back to north. Before the compass, sailors had to navigate by the stars — if it was cloudy, they were lost! The compass changed everything about exploration and trade.'

'The last Great Invention is GUNPOWDER. Chinese alchemists were actually trying to create a potion for eternal life! Instead, they accidentally made a mixture that EXPLODES. At first, they used it for fireworks — those were invented in China too! Later it was used in weapons, completely changing warfare.'

slides.prompt: Create a 'Four Great Inventions of China' poster. For each invention (paper, printing, compass, gunpowder), include: a drawing, the approximate date of invention, a short description, and how it changed the world. Make it colorful and informative!

slides.text: Paper, printing, the compass, and gunpowder — four inventions from Ancient China that changed the course of human history. All four spread across the world via the Silk Road. Next week, we travel west to Ancient Greece!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student name all Four Great Inventions of China and explain the significance of each?

parent_notes: The Four Great Inventions of China are a cornerstone of world history education. The compass experiment (magnetizing a needle and floating it on water) is a wonderful hands-on science activity. Gunpowder's origin as a failed medicine is a great example of accidental discovery in science. These inventions all traveled the Silk Road — reinforce that connection from earlier this week.

title: Read Aloud — Chinese Folktale
description: A read-aloud of a traditional Chinese folktale, connecting to the Ancient China unit. Students explore themes, morals, and cultural values reflected in the story.
instructions:
1. Choose a Chinese folktale (suggestions: 'The Empty Pot' by Demi, 'Lon Po Po' by Ed Young, or 'The Seven Chinese Brothers').
2. Before reading: 'What is a folktale? A story passed down through generations that teaches a lesson.'
3. Read the story aloud with expression and pauses for prediction.
4. After reading: discuss the theme/moral. What lesson does the story teach?
5. Compare to folktales from other cultures — do any have similar themes?
6. Students write the moral of the story and draw their favorite scene.
7. Share responses.

slides.setup_instructions: Select a Chinese folktale appropriate for ages 6-9. Preview and mark discussion points. 'The Empty Pot' by Demi is excellent and widely available.

slides.text: 'All week we have been learning about Ancient China. Today we will read a folktale — a story that Chinese families have told their children for hundreds of years. Folktales carry the values and wisdom of a culture.' Introduce the book and show the cover.

Read the story aloud with expression. Pause at key moments: 'What do you think will happen next? Why do you think the character did that? What would YOU do in this situation?' Encourage predictions and connections.

After reading: 'What lesson does this story teach? This lesson is called the MORAL or THEME of the story.' Discuss Chinese cultural values that appear: honesty, respect for elders, hard work, wisdom. 'Do you know any stories from other cultures that teach a similar lesson?'

slides.prompt: In your reading journal: (1) Write the title and a one-sentence summary of the story. (2) Write the moral/lesson of the story. (3) Draw your favorite scene with as much detail as possible. (4) Write one sentence about how this story connects to what you learned about China this week.

slides.text: Folktales help us understand what a culture values most. Chinese folktales often teach about honesty, patience, cleverness, and respect. This week we traveled through Ancient China — its Great Wall, Silk Road, inventions, geography, art, and stories. What an amazing civilization!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify the moral of a folktale and connect it to the cultural context of Ancient China?

parent_notes: Chinese folktales are rich with wisdom and often feature themes of honesty, humility, and respect for nature. 'The Empty Pot' by Demi is perhaps the best-known Chinese picture book in English — its message about honesty is universal. After reading, explore more Chinese folktales at the library. Each one opens a window into Chinese values and traditions. This closes our Ancient China unit beautifully.
